result.execSummary:
The defendant Nicole J. Golomski was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Battery [Modifiers: Repeater], a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 940.19(1).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

miscConds.notes:
Obtain and maintain full time employment or schooling or a combination of both to equal full time.
Participate  with other assessments as recommended by the agent.
Participate  with other assessments as recommended by the agent.

If probation is discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil Judgment will be entered against the Defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due. All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt. Per Wisconsin Statute, funds from prison accounts may be used for obligations in accordance with prison policy not to exceed 25% of gross.

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Nicole J. Golomski

records.descr: Records of prosec. are converted data. See file.

records.addlTxt: Conditional Release Letter filed by Andrea Den Otter, LCSW, SAC - original filed in 13CF372

Defendant Nicole J. Golomski in court with attorney Gary J. Kryshak. Defendant Nicole J. Golomski in custody. David R. Knaapen appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
Cases heard at this time are 13TR-2022, 2023, 15CF-287, 15CM-288 and 15CT-94.

10:32 AM Court calls cases.
Atty Knaapen states appearances.

There is a plea agreement.

15CF-287
State has filed an amended information.
Defendant will plead to amended charge.
withd, prob 24 mo, no con with Jenna Mosey, ft emt/school, other counseling recommended, court costs, no request for restitition

State has complied with victim notification statutes.

15CM-288
Defendant will plead to Count 1 and Count 3
Count 2 would be dismissed and read in
30 day jail each count concurrent/consecutive, costs

15CT-94
13TR-2022
13TR-2023
These would be dismissed and read in

Atty Kryshak concurs.

Defendant concurs.

Plea questionnaire/Agreement filed.

Defendant enters a plea of: NO CONTEST 15CF-287: Amended Count 1
Defendant enters a plea of: NO CONTEST 15CM-288 Count 1 
Defendant enters a plea of: NO CONTEST 15CM-288 Count 3 

Court questions Defendant regarding pleas.
Court informs Defendant of Constitutional Rights. Court advises Defendant of Elements State must prove for the Charge.
Court questions Attorney Kryshak for Defendant.
Court finds Defendant's Plea is freely, voluntarily and intelligently made.
Attorneys stipulate that there is factual basis for the charges.

Court reviews the criminal complaints.

BY THE COURT:
Court finds a sufficient factual basis to support the charges.
Court finds the defendant guilty.  Clerk directed to enter Judgment of Conviction this date.
15CF-287: Count 1: Amended Count: Misdemeanor Battery as a repeat offender
15CM-288: Count 1: Misdemeanor Bailjumping charge as a repeater
15CM-288: Count 2: Dismissed and Read In
15CM-288: Count 3: Operate without valid license 3rd offense
15CT-94: Dismissed and Read In
13TR-2022: Dismissed and Read In
13TR-2023: Dismissed and Read In

Atty Knaapen makes sentencing arguments to the Court. 
Defendant is in custody on a Wood County case at the moment.
Atty Kryshak makes sentencing arguments to the Court, requests jail sentence to run concurrent to current sentence Defendant is serving.

Defendant addresses the Court prior to sentencing.

Court has a number of factors to consider to determine sentencing.

BY THE COURT:
15CM-288
Count 1:
Jail sentence of 30 Days, consecutive to any other sentence Defendant is serving
15 Days Jail Credit
Huber granted for work, counseling and any other reason the Sheriff will allow
May be served on electronic monitor if Defendant is approved from the assessments
Report to jail today
Sentence to commence within 60 days from being released from current jail sentence she is serving
Pay costs
Provide DNA Sample

Count 3:
Jail sentence of 30 Days, concurrent to Count 1, but consecutive to any other sentence Defendant is serving
15 Days Jail Credit
Huber granted for work, counseling and any other reason the Sheriff will allow
May be served on electronic monitor if Defendant is approved from the assessments
Report to jail today
Sentence to commence within 60 days from being released from current jail sentence she is serving
Pay costs

15CF-287
Count 1: Amended
Jail sentence for 30 Days, consecutive with any other sentence Defendant is serving, Imposed and Stayed
Huber granted for work, counseling and any other reason the Sheriff will allow
Probation for a period of 24 Months
Conditions:
No contact with Jenna Mosey
Obtain and maintain full time employment or schooling or a combination of both to equal full time
Participate  with other assessments as recommended by the agent
Pay costs
Ad Prosequendum with attached Writ of Habeas Corpus Ad Prosequendum /s/ TBE 03/14/16

records.addlTxt: Plea hearing on April 6, 2016 at 10:30 am.

Attorney Gary J. Kryshak in court. David R. Knaapen appeared for the Portage County.
9:58 a.m.  Court calls the cases. 
All cases heard:  13TR2022, 13TR2023, 15CF287, 15CM288, 15CT94

Atty Kryshak indicates the defendant is currently in the Wood County Jail.  Asks to adjourn to allow for a writ.  Plea hearing scheduled for April 6, 2016 at 10:30 am.

State files Information.
Defendant received copy of information.
Defendant waives reading of information. 

NOT GUILTY Plea(s) entered.

Bond Continued.

Defendant Nicole J. Golomski in court with attorney Ryan Drengler. David Knaapen appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  
Defendant waives right to preliminary hearing. 
Court questions defendant regarding waiver of preliminary hearing. 
Court questions Attorney.
Court finds the defendant has freely, voluntarily and intelligently waived the preliminary hearing. 
On the defendants waiver of the preliminary hearing, Court determines, based on the facts contained in the complaint, there is sufficient probable cause and binds the defendant over for trial.  Pre-trial conference scheduled for November 9, 2015 at 10:30 am.
